evidence.pdf_reference: The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 into methanol over TiO 2 , NiO, and ZnO was studied by irradiating the saturated solution of CO 2 in 70 ml of deionized water containing a suspension of the optimum amount of the above-mentioned semiconductor powders.A Pyrex cell (35 mm diameter and 120 mm length), equipped with optical grade quartz windows for transmission of UV laser beam was designed and fabricated.The cell was equipped with ports and rubber septa for liquid and gas sampling.In order to study the

produced in the presence of CO 2 , over TiO 2 , NiO, and ZnO, was measured and plotted in comparison with that of the hydrogen produced in argon environment (without CO 2 ) under similar experimental conditions; see Figs. 345.A substantial decrease in hydrogen evolution was observed for all the catalysts in the presence of CO 2 .This points to the insertion of H ions in CO 2 to give CH 3 OH.The pH changes (Fig. 2) in the course of the photocatalytic process supports the involvement of H ions in

the multi-electronic processes (Eqs.( 8)-( 12)) are more favorable; they require much less energy per electron transferred as compared to mono-electron process (Eq.7).A simple tool, in photocatalytic processes, to study the feasibility of a reaction occurring is the position of the conduction and valance band edges.These band edges predict directly the occurrence of a reaction.The conduction band potentials of the catalysts (TiO 2 , NiO, and ZnO) used in this study are A0.29,A0.5 and A0.31 V, respectively,

of H 2 CO 3 is of acidic nature and generates H and carbonate ions. The comparison of the amount of methanol produced from the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 , over TiO 2 , NiO, and ZnO, as a function of time, is presented in Fig. 1.It is observed that for TiO 2 and ZnO there is an increase followed by a sharp decrease in the yield of methanol while for NiO there is an initial sharp increase followed by a gradual decrease.Other side products observed in the process were CH 3 COOH (in the liquid phase)

of methanol. By comparing, the potentials of the reactions given in Eqs. ( 13)- (20) with that of the conduction band potentials of the catalysts under study, it can be inferred that the route of methanol formation in Eqs. ( 13)-( 20) is more thermodynamically favorable compared to the route in Eqs. the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 into methanol, the optimum amount of photocatalysts, ( 300 mg) was suspended in 70 ml of doubly distilled deionized water.Before irradiation, the colloidal suspension was saturated with CO 2 by passing the CO 2 through the suspension at a flow rate of 150 ml min for a period of 15 min.The suspension was then irradiated for 90 min with the optimum laser energy of 355 nm pulsed laser.A 355 nm laser beam, was generated from the third harmonic of a Spectra Physics Nd:YAG

Selective photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 into methanol, using 355 nm UV laser as a light source, has been studied for the first time.An alternate route for the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 , based on thermodynamic viability of the process, has been suggested.It was observed that the formation of methanol from CO 2 is a reversible process and the methanol produced during the photocatalytic process degrades to generate hydrogen and CO 2 again; which hampers the over all conversion rate.The measurements
